Another proof of 1/h² = 1/a² + 1/b² follows from the pythagorean theorem, when you consider that the area of a triangle is base * height/2. Area² = base² * height² / 4, and you can choose the base freely. If you consider a to be the base, then Area² = a² * b² / 4, but if you choose c as your base, the height of the triangle is h, so Area² = c² * h² / 4. Now
4 * Area² / a² = b²,
4 * Area² / b² = a²,
4 * Area² / h² = c².

By Pythagoras, a² + b² = c², so 4 * Area² ( 1 / a² + 1/b²) = 4 * Area² (1 / h²). Divide both sides by 4 * Area² and you get 1 / a² + 1 / b² = 1 / h², no triangles that are only congruent in the limit needed.

Love this channel, though I’d like to point out that in this limiting case in which you get a straight line, the number of lighthouses contributing to the sum divided by the total number of lighthouses (including the ones at the other end of the infinite circle) approaches zero. It means that for each lighthouse in the sum there are infinitely many lighthouses along the circumference that are neglected. In a sense the limiting case is that 0 percent of all the lighthouses are taken into account and 100% of the lighthouses are neglected. Of course, the neglected lighthouses are infinitely long distance apart, so their total contributions to the apparent brightness approach 0 as the circle diameter approaches infinity.

Very impressive, yes, but unfortunately there is a huge gap in the proof.
At 14:00, you magically transform the circle into a line.
It is not at all obvious how this works.
For example, however large the circle is, there are always some (and in fact very many in the limit) lighthouses almost straight above the origin. How are they going to "disappear" in the limit?
To fill the gap, you need some kind of "uniform continuity" or "can swap the order of limits" property, or arguments similar to those used to apply the residue theorem to solve real integrals.
As it is presented, the video is a typical example of "fake math": Show all the steps that can be understood easily in all details, using impressive graphics and animations, even making unnecessary generalizations, but then skip the one step that needs "higher" mathematical methods and hide the gap conveniently behind those graphics and animations (here: showing only a tiny part of the circle when it transforms into a line).

SOMETHING ELSE I TOOK AWAY FROM THIS EXCELLENT VIDEO:
THE IMPLICATION OF CIRCLES: STRAIGHT LINES = CURVES
This means that any path from A to B can be understood as a straight line (like a diameter) and as a curve (like the half-circumference of a circle), and in fact, that a straight line is a special case of a curve, and a curve is the special case of a straight line.

There seems to be no mathematical reasoning unless one can conceive of a curve as a straight line, and vice versa. The foundations of Maths seem to require the concepts of zero and infinity (and the right angle) in order to understand the finite world of 1, 2, 3, .... Alternatively, Maths simply requires the concept of a circle, which has a straight diameter and a curved circumference both starting at one point (A) and both reaching the other (B), and back again.

If one takes the curve of the half circumference of the circle to go from A to B (the diameter being AB), one is not taking a curve but a straight line that is perpendicular to the direction of the line AB. It is curious how this perpendicular straight line that passes through A becomes the curve of a circle, bending towards B through infinitely short straight lines that turn (while keeping straight) towards B.

On the other hand, if one goes directly from A towards B (as if in a straight line), one is actually taking an extreme curve that points one in the direction of B from A.

An extreme curve (i.e. a straight line) is formed as follows: First assume that the circle has an infinite diameter (A on the one end and passing through B to infinity), in which case one will never reach B, as circle with infinite diameter becomes a straight line passing through A perpendicular to the line AB (in other words, the circle is transformed from two dimensions into one). But as one decreases that infinite diameter into a finite amount, the circle becomes a two dimensional object, and the curve that passes through A eventually reaches B (when the diameter is AB). At first, this curve is very gradual, and as one decreases the diameter, the curve becomes steeper and steeper, pointing one closer and closer in the direction from A directly towards B. As the diameter of the circle approaches zero, the circle loses both dimensions (as it becomes a point at A), and the curve of its circumference becomes so extreme that it points one directly in the direction of B. That curve was, in the first place, a series of infinitely short straight-lines, which started perpendicular to the line AB, and now is a circle with an infinitely small diameter, but pointing in the direction to AB.

Thus straight lines can turn in a circle (and return to the origin), and a circle can point in a direction from one point to another! The curve of this (pointing) circle (with infinitely small diameter) is in fact the derivative: it gives the direction of the movement without directly joining two points on that path. Effectively, the straight line of the curve that one followed perpendicular to AB has been turned 90 degrees so that it now points from A to B.

The path of A to B is thus to be conceived as both a straight line (a determined path) joining A and B and equivalently as only a direction centred at A that points to B, but does not connect A and B (no determined path). To reach B, one must move in the direction of the path with a certain hope and expectation that B will be reached (because there is determined no line or curve joining the two points, only a point at one's location A pointing towards B).

Thus the path from A to B is an extreme curve of infinitely small circles (at each point between A and B) which do not join any of the points on the path, but are centred at A and at each point on the path (at every new A approaching B), and point in the direction of B.

ANOTHER IMPLICATION OF CIRCLES: INFINITE SUM OF RATIONALS = IRRATIONAL
It would seem that irrational numbers are the infinite sum of rational numbers, and vice versa. One cannot multiple two rational numbers and get an irrational number, yet an irrational number (which is necessary to conceive of a circle) is the infinite sum of rational numbers, and vice versa. Infinity and zero (the infinitely small) have the ability to equate rational and irrational numbers. That is how circles are conceived.

If the diameter (from point A to B) is rational (e.g. 2), then half-circumference (from A to B) will be irrational (i.e. pi), and if the half-circumference is rational (e.g. 1), then the diameter is irrational (i.e. 1/pi). Both rational and irrational concepts guide one from any point A to any point B, either following a curve or a straight line making use of the concepts of infinity and zero (infinitely small).

Because physical reality seems to have quantum levels for space-time-energy (as a kind of pixelated reality), thus the concepts of infinity and zero are beyond this reality (though perceived by the mind), and the nearest real quantum to both is where physical reality appears to end and to begin, when one traverses the real distance A to B.

Sum of series = PI^2/ 6 = PI/2 * PI/3
equivalent to PI radians/2* PI radians /3
equivalent to 180/2*180/3 degrees = 90 * 60 degrees expressed as radians
Since: 1 radian = 57.296 degrees; 90 degrees = 1.57079 rad; 60 degrees = 1.04719 rad
PI^2/6 = 1.57079 * 1.04719 = 1.6449 rad
So how did Euler work out that an infinite convergent geometric series would be equal to the product of 90 and 60 degrees expressed as radians, when the series is the sum the reciprocals of the squares of integers from 1, 2, 3, ...n?

Take this circles within circles within circles idea, where the outer one is twice the circumference of the inner one, and picture epicycycles where the inner circles could be rolling inside of each other like an infinite set of spirographs. I think this fits well with the idea of splitting the lighthouses into two new ones if you can imagine a lighthouse on an inner circle "depositing" a copy of itself where it contacts the outer circle and later depositing another copy on the opposite side of the circle. The new set of lighthouses rolls around another circle doing the same thing, ad infinitum. Two thoughts: first, it’s helpful to note that the fact that it’s a right angle subtended by a diameter from a point on the circle is just a special case of the inscribed angle theorem where the central angle is 180 degrees. It’s a nice way to cover both theorems with the same underlying fact.

Second, since the video is taking a physics perspective with the light analogy, I thought I’d point out a physical proof to understand the theorem you mentioned at 8:00. Notice that the area of the slender triangles is half the cross product of the short “screen” vector and the distance between the screen and lighthouse. So the amount of light hitting the screen can be thought of as a torque, where the displacement between the screen and lighthouse is the radius, and the screen vector is the force. Then you can use the physical concept of calculating torques using the “moment arm” technique (the torque remains constant no matter at which point along the perpendicular the force is applied), which turns out to be the same as what we want to prove here. A nice exposition of how numbers follow Euclidean Geometry...not the other way around as so often misstated. It is too bad Euclidean Geometry is so neglected in schools. It is the foundation of Western Civilization. It shouldn't surprise anyone (but it does!) that the radius 'walks' the circumference of the circle EXACTLY 6 times. The types of triangles are all found by the relation of radii and chords in a circle. As shown, the diameter of any circle will be the hypotenuse of any and all right triangles, with the center point as the midpoint on the hypotenuse. Iscosceles triangles have the center point as the angle formed by the two radii or 'equal sides' and the scalene triangle is any random chords which do not intersect the center point of the circle.

It is quite easy to show that number patterns are intrinsically following the geometry of the circle, but to this day, no one understands this. This little exposition shows nicely how that statement is true. It also touches on what is meant by 'Infinity' and how that term is also routinely misapplied. There are more problems, of a simple definitive nature in mathematics than is generally allowed.

This exposition, however, was a very nice bit of work.

I actually was a bit confused between the statement at 6:10 that "the brightness the observer experiences from the first lighthouse is equal to the combined brightness experienced from lighthouse A and B" and your proof at 8:00
After thinking about I realized the following:

Given a fixed screen (let's say the scaled down hypothenuse), it is not true that the brightness that that screen receives from lighthouse H is equal to the sum of brightnesses from lighthouses A and B, on that screen! The inverse pythagorean theorem doesn't imply that, because although the brightness per unit area is 1/r^2, given the fixed screen area, one needs to multiply by the cosine of the angle between the screen normal and position vector of the lighthouse to get the brightness incident on the screen!

Now, why did this confuse me? Because the demonstration at 8:00 (which I checked using some geometry) said that the angle subtended by the screen from lighthouse H equals the sum of angles suspended from lighthouse A and B. Furthermore, the video makes you think that angle subtended == brightness on screen (at least infinitesimaly). This is true! But only in 2D and when brightness decreases like 1/r. In, 3D, with brightness decreasing like 1/r^2, it is the subtended solid angle that matters, and in this same setup, but extended to 3D, the solid angle subtended by the fixed screen at lighthouse H is not the same as the sum of solid angles subtended at lighthouses A and B!

In summary, I think the demonstration at 8:00, inspired by the thing said at 6:10, actually makes things more confusing, because it is not true that the Inverse Pythagorean theorem is equivalent to the thing said at 6:10, when taken as a statement in 3D. It is true, when taken as a statement in 2D (demonstration at 8:00), but when assuming light intensity decays as 1/r, which goes against what's said in the rest of the video!

You can also use Gauss's law to approach the same solution, rather than a geometric approach. Gauss's law works since a radially symmetric field that's magnitude weakens via the inverse square law has its radius term fall out in a surface integral. This means no matter where the lighthouses are within a sphere of radius R, they can be represented by a single lighthouse of combined magnitude in its center. This also means that same combined lighthouse can be represented by equally spaced, equally lit lighthouses along its boundary. By using this law within a cylinder, and holding the "lighthouse surface density" to be 1/2, you find the surface integral to equal to π^2, and a quarter of the cylinder is π^2/4, the same result as using the geometric method.

(The circle is quartered to eliminate lighthouses on the negative side of the number line, and double counting when the number line curves upwards to form the circle)
